awd_titl_txt: Pricing the Priceless Spacecraft: The Social Life of Money in Robotic Planetary Exploration
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent economic crisis has created havoc for public funding of big science projects, especially those that rely on long term support. Yet it is often difficult to determine the effects of this fiscal uncertainty on the technologies, communities, and scientific findings that such funding is meant to support. This project uses the case study of NASA spacecraft mission teams to examine how scientists secure, maintain, and compete for funding during moments of financial crisis, with an eye to how these activities affect scientific and technical results. The research offers policy implications for public funding. During times of greater fiscal scrutiny and austerity, federal agencies and policy-makers require data-driven understanding of the consequences for long-term scientific and technical innovation that are associated with trade-offs in funding levels and priority-setting. 
 
This project accumulates archival, interview, and budgetary data across three periods of fiscal uncertainty endured by six spacecraft missions: the late 1960s and early 70s (Mariner 10 and Viking), the "lost" 1980s (Galileo and Mars Observer), and the "faster, better, cheaper" era of the 1990s (Cassini and Pathfinder). The research assembles as comprehensive a dataset as possible on the specific technical and scientific changes on the ground due to budgetary crises, combining oral history interviews with project managers and cost estimators with hard numbers accumulated in reports. Planetary science is accustomed to budgetary upheavals and has developed many strategies to mitigate the impact of fiscal uncertainty.  The fiscal backdrop for each of these missions illuminates the social and interactional mechanisms for securing funding as well as the ultimate effects of financial decision-making upon scientific work. Thus unlike studies of technology or science that frame funding as an external affair, or that examine science and politics as separate fields, this case demonstrates how science funding is a continual process woven through scientific work, requiring many layered relationships between individuals and institutions. The project therefore unites many social science fields including history and sociology of science, economic sociology, historical sociology and the science of team science, to investigate the impact of fiscal challenges on scientific collaboration, integration and dissemination.

por.por_cntn:
How do the slings and arrows of fiscal fortune affect scientific work? And why do big science projects always seem to go so far over budget? This project answers these two pressing questions through comparative study of NASA's robotic space exploration program, past and present. NASA presents an interesting case due to its mandated single point of funding (via Congress) and bounded community of experts. We followed a mission team ethnographically as they sought to establish their project during the period of fiscal and political uncertainty in the twenty-teens, and assembled historical documentation since the 1960's to piece together a story about science funding and the long term impacts of funding fluctuations.

The result is a new narrative about how to think about and analyze the role of money in scientific projects, drawing on socioeconomics and on our extensive data: in short, it's people.We found that the vast majority of cost overruns are not due to technical problems, but due to people; that up to 30-40% of "invisible" funding goes to employees, institutional overhead, and meeting costs (what one PI called "the 25% tax"). We demonstrate how scientists and engineers construct (and reconstruct) a multi-relational "tradespace" in which new values for pieces, parts, and people are constantly renegotiated. We also show how the shifts away from funding institutional partnerships toward grants funding has produced new incentives as money for workforce keeps the lights on at institutions, even as it keeps those individuals in precarious circumstances. Ultimately, the fluctuating value attached to projects in science relies upon and reflects shifting relationships among members of a scientific field and its funding agencies.

Just like studies of money in intimate relationships, in business partnerships, or in personal loans, then, money in science is never external to the scientific enterprise, corrupting it from the outside or a measure of how poorly scientists plan for the future. Money and cost is a measure of how scientists and engineers manage their relationships with each other. Seeing the people in the money, we argue, helps us to ascertain why budgets go so far astray, why and how "descopes" end up producing long term effects on communities and scientific possibilities, how scientists develop alternative currencies and exchange rates to manage relational ties, how they "account" for their time and energy, and what risks long term projects face as they encounter the fiscally unexpected on their way to their investigations.

The main outcome of this project is a book project, currently being written and expected in published form in 2023. In the interim, we have published two articles in Social Studies of Science with another article underway. We have also released a public dataset of our historical findings, available in an open repository. We have spoken about our findings at top conferences in science studies and in the sciences. We have also collaborated with science teams at NASA interested in fiscally sustaining their collaborations over the long term, resulting in white papers, conference talks and publications. A followup RAPID grant builds on this body of knowledge to examine the period of COVID19 disruptions and its effects on science and science funding. This grant also participated in training an emerging young social scientist.

  • David Reinecke and Janet Vertesi (2023). Fund this! Big Science in an Age of Austerity (in preparation)

Articles:

  • David Reinecke, When funding fails: Planetary exploration at NASA in an era of austerity, 1967?1976. Soc Stud Sci. 51, 750?779 (2021).
  • David Reinecke and Jordan Bimm. Sustaining the Search for Life: The Maintenance of Ambiguity in Martian Exobiology Following Non-Detection Events. Accepted to Soc Stud Sci. (expected 2021).
